entry.title: Everything My Mom Taught Me about Change Management for AI in Procurement
entry.content:
A Story about Change Done Right

Growing up, our dinner table conversations were a mix of stories about our day. My dad, a computer programmer for a large tech company, would talk about coding languages and mainframes, while my mom would share stories about her accounting role at a regional office for a global organization. Back then, I found myself leaning in whenever she talked about big changes happening at her office. 

What struck me, even as a kid, was a clear pattern: when changes were significant, her leadership team went above and beyond to make the office environment collaborative and supportive. They held town halls, brought in specialized trainers, and one memorable summer they even had an ice cream truck visit the office every Friday.  

I realize now that her leadership team understood something fundamental, which is that successful change management isn’t just about rolling out new tools, it’s about considering the human impact. My mom happily worked for that organization for years and even recruited me to intern there. That’s the power of thoughtful change management. 

So how can you model what my mom experienced when implementing AI in SAP Ariba or SAP Fieldglass? Let's look at the playbook. 

Clear Communications: Everyone Deserves to Know the “Why” 

The first lesson from my mom's experience was transparency. Her leadership team didn't just announce changes, they explained the "why" behind their decisions and created multiple ways for employees to understand and engage.  

When you're implementing AI in procurement, develop a robust communication strategy that addresses where you're deploying it and the rationale behind those choices. Maybe you’re: 

  • Rolling out the AI-assisted SAP Ariba Category Management solution because it saves your team multiple hours per week by automating category analysis, enabling them to become strategic advisors with better data and faster identification of new business opportunities. 
  • Piloting intelligent resume analysis in SAP Fieldglass because it highlights top talent for hiring managers, giving them more time to focus on their core responsibilities while gaining a competitive advantage in talent acquisition. 

Be upfront about your reasoning. Use multiple communication channels that feel natural to your organization. Town halls work well for big-picture strategy and allowing open questions. "Ask Me Anything" sessions give employees a safe space to voice concerns. But don't stop there - weave updates into established channels like company newsletters, team meetings, and other standardized communications your teams already utilize and trust. 

Most importantly, identify and leverage internal champions early in your communication strategy. These trusted team members can help translate technical concepts into practical benefits and address concerns from their peers’ perspective. When your teams have questions, take the time to answer them thoughtfully. This isn't just courtesy; it's essential for adoption. 

Special Training Programs: Don't Skip This Step 

Here’s where many organizations stumble. They want to skip comprehensive training and assume people will figure out AI-driven tools on their own. Don’t make this mistake. 

First, Get Your Data Foundation Right 

Before you can train effectively, you need clean data. AI works best when the underlying data is structured, reliable, and consistently maintained, but many procurement organizations struggle with data that’s scattered across systems. Supplier names often vary between purchase orders and contracts and spend categories don’t align across business units. This fragmentation creates obstacles to adoption. 

That’s why you need to start by explaining how AI works within your solutions. When a user sees an AI-generated recommendation in SAP Ariba or an AI-generated statement of work (SOW) description in SAP Fieldglass, they should understand which data inputs created that content and why it matters.  

Then, Focus on User Training  

  • With Joule, show users how conversational AI accesses your organization’s information and best practices, demonstrating why instant access to critical data improves their decision-making capabilities 
  • With SAP Ariba, help users understand how market and historical data analysis creates real-time category strategy, supplier insights, and RFP recommendations, enabling them to make confident decisions and respond faster to changing conditions  
  • With SAP Fieldglass, explain how basic project inputs generate comprehensive descriptions for both job descriptions and SOWs, so hiring managers can trust AI-enhanced deliverables while focusing on strategic workforce planning 

Finally, Nurture and Support your Champions 

Your champions will help drive your success and should also be involved in validating AI recommendations during pilot phases. When they can vouch for the accuracy and usefulness of AI-generated insights, your solutions will be more impactful and their endorsement will carry a lot of weight, just like my mom’s feedback did at her organization. Keep your champions engaged by recognizing their contributions publicly, providing them with exclusive previews of new features, and regularly asking them for their input on product improvements. Personalized attention helps maintain their enthusiasm and advocacy.  

Your team won't automatically love new features just because they're AI-driven. You need to train them properly, communicate quick wins clearly, and continuously drive adoption.   

Ice Cream for Everyone: The Human Element Matters 

That summer, my mom made it her mission to try every flavor from that ice cream truck. She’d come home excited to tell us about both the ice cream and the wins, big and small, that her team was racking up with their new processes. And the best part? The changes let her spend more time digging into the more interesting, complex invoices instead of processing the easy ones that were never flagged.   

The small gestures mattered as much as the robust communication plans and training programs, creating an environment where change felt celebratory rather than threatening. 

Don't underestimate the human element that comes with any significant change. While AI-enabled solutions like SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass ensure there's always a human in the loop, people still feel natural apprehension about adopting tools that are designed to drive efficiency. They wonder if their expertise will still be valued, if their jobs will change, or if they'll be able to master new ways of working.  

Address this directly by highlighting how AI creates opportunities for greater visibility and strategic impact. For example:   

  • Joule eliminates information bottlenecks by making information conversationally accessible. It puts details like purchasing insights and hiring best practices at users’ fingertips. 
  • Sourcing and Bid Analysis Agents in SAP Ariba solutions reduce decision-making stress and increase agility by analyzing market and historical data to create and adapt RFPs in real time. This gives users confidence in purchasing decisions and faster responses to supply chain disruptions while freeing them to focus on negotiations and relationship building. 
  • The SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution elevates user roles by automating invoice processing where key thresholds are met. This reduces manual data entry so teams can focus on high-value exception management and build stronger vendor relationships. 
  • AI-assisted SOW creation tools in SAP Fieldglass applications streamline project planning by generating comprehensive descriptions from basic project inputs, enabling hiring managers to create detailed SOWs faster. The tools also drive consistency across templates and projects, which helps users shift from administrative workforce management to strategic talent optimization. 

The key is showing employees that AI elevates their expertise rather than replacing it, much like how my mom's new systems and processes made her work more strategic and less manual.  

Change Management Best Practices Actually Work 

Successful AI adoption follows the same change management approach that worked for my mom's organization years ago: clear communication, comprehensive training, genuine support, and celebration of progress. It’s a timeless template for transformation. 

  • Communicate clearly and frequently about what's changing and why. 
  • Invest in comprehensive training that's tailored for all skill levels. 
  • Create opportunities for feedback and iteration. 
  • Acknowledge that change is challenging and provide support.   

Most importantly, keep the human experience at the center of your implementation strategy. Technology should make people's work more interesting and valuable, not more complicated or uncertain.   

When procurement professionals can spend less time on data compilation and more time on strategic initiatives, have better insights to inform negotiations, and respond more quickly to business needs — that's when AI becomes fun and transformational.  

By getting this right, you ensure that your teams won't just adopt AI, they'll become advocates for it. They’ll share success stories and help scale the transformation across your organization, and they'll talk about how much fun they’re having at the dinner table, just like my mom did.  

Ready to optimize your company's approach to AI? Check out the AI-based solutions that are already embedded in your SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass applications on our SAP Business AI for procurement webpage.

entry.title: Achieving Best-in-Class Invoice Exception KPIs in SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing
entry.content:
One of the clearest indicators of efficiency in an AP organization is the percentage of invoices that can be processed without an exception. Best-in-class performers consistently achieve 85–90% (or higher) invoice-throughput with zero exceptions. Many SAP Ariba customers operate far below that—often without realizing how much time, cost, and user frustration gets tied up in exception handling.

As part of the SAP Ariba Solution Value Advisory team, we work with customers every day to improve adoption and unlock measurable business value. And one consistent theme we see?
Within SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing or SAP Ariba Invoice Management,  when the “invoices without exceptions” KPI is low, it’s usually a sign that key reporting insights or powerful configuration options aren’t being fully leveraged. Many customers set these tolerances and exception rules at their go-live and never revisit them—even as their supplier base, purchasing patterns, and business priorities evolve. The good news is that by analyzing the right reports and adjusting targeted configuration settings, this KPI can be improved quickly and sustainably.

Let’s walk through why this matters, what you should measure, and how to improve it using SAP Ariba best practices.

Why This KPI Matters

Improving your exception-free invoice rate isn’t just about efficiency—it directly impacts:

1. Faster Invoice Cycle Times

Fewer exceptions mean fewer delays. Suppliers get paid quicker. AP teams get out of firefighting mode.

2. Stronger Supplier Relationships

Consistent processing builds trust, predictability, and reduces the back-and-forth inquiries.

3. Lower Operating Cost

Exception handling is expensive. Every unnecessary rework loop adds labor hours.

4. Better User Experience

Buyers, receivers, and AP processors spend less time resolving issues and more time on strategic work.

5. Clean Data Feeding Analytics & Automation

A cleaner invoice process unlocks more opportunities for automation, validations, and future optimization.

Step 1: Measure What’s Really Happening

Before solving problems, you need a clear look at them.

I always recommend customers start by running the following in SAP Ariba:

Exception Reports by:

  • Exception type

  • Supplier

  • Commodity

This gives a precise view of where your exceptions are coming from. Often, 80% of issues originate from 10–15 suppliers or a handful of commodities.

This becomes your roadmap.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Supplier

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Supplier

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each supplier.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Commodity

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Commodity

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each Commodity L2.

Interpret the Results and Identify Where to Act

Once you’ve run your exception reports by supplier and commodity, the real value comes from how you use the findings. This is where customers often unlock quick wins.

Start by reviewing:

  • Which suppliers generate the highest number of exceptions

  • Which commodities consistently trigger the same exception types

  • Patterns across PO types or line items

In most organizations, a small group of suppliers or categories is responsible for the majority of exceptions. This makes your next steps much more focused and targeted.

Use the Data to Drive Configuration Improvements

If you see that receiving exceptions are concentrated around certain suppliers or commodities, this is a strong indicator that your receiving process may not fit how those suppliers operate. For example, many high-volume, fast-shipping suppliers (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, IT accessories, etc.) ship and invoice so quickly that end users rarely have time to receive the items manually.

This is exactly where SAP Ariba’s configuration options can help.

Step 2: Strategy & Configuration Options to Improve Your KPI

Below are the most effective levers that customers have used to reduce invoice exceptions and move toward best-in-class performance.

1. Use Auto-Receiving for High-Velocity, Low-Risk Suppliers

If you see a high volume of receiving exceptions for certain suppliers—especially those who ship quickly (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, safety, IT peripherals)—auto-receiving can significantly improve your throughput.

Why this works

Many of these suppliers ship and invoice same-day. That leaves almost no time for end users to receive goods manually. Auto-receipt ensures:

  • Fewer receiving exceptions

  • Faster invoice processing

  • Less burden on casual users

How to configure

Auto-receiving can be based on:

  • Supplier & Supplier Part Number or by only Supplier 

  • Commodity

2. Review and Adjust Tax Exception Tolerances

Tax exceptions are common, especially in jurisdictions where suppliers calculate tax differently or round amounts differently.

How to improve

  • Review your current tax variance tolerances

  • Identify suppliers consistently triggering small variances

  • Adjust tolerances to realistic levels aligned with procurement policy

This can be strategically relaxed only where justified—not globally.

3. Evaluate Shipping Cost Tolerances

Shipping exceptions often occur when:

  • The supplier charges small shipping amounts not included on the PO 

  • When outside a stated percentage tolerance of the invoice amount

Options

  • Set reasonable shipping % tolerances

  • Use flat-rate dollar tolerances for specific suppliers

  • Update templates for certain commodities where shipping is always variable

4. Leverage Invoice Exception Overrides (By Supplier or Commodity)

This is one of the most under-used but highly effective tools SAP Ariba customers have.

What They Are

Invoice exception overrides allow you to set:

  • Different tolerance percentages

  • Different dollar limits

For specific suppliers, commodity codes, or currency.

Why It Matters

Most exceptions are not systemic—they are concentrated. Overrides let you tune the system where the problem exists, without weakening global controls.

Examples

  • For a trusted supplier with a predictable pattern, allow a slightly higher price variance.

  • For a commodity where tax always fluctuates (e.g., services), apply more flexible thresholds.

  • Ensure to adjust amount tolerances per currency

5. Work With Suppliers When Exceptions Follow a Pattern

Sometimes exceptions are not a configuration issue, but a supplier process issue.

Consider supplier-facing improvements such as:

  • Reinforcing PO-Flip usage

  • Ensuring suppliers invoice based on PO quantities only

  • Updating supplier enablement documentation

  • Aligning catalog pricing with contracts

  • Negotiating tax and shipping behavior

Remember—suppliers want faster invoice processing too.

Step 3: Communicate Improvements and Track Progress

Once you’ve implemented changes, measure the impact:

  • Exception rate by supplier month-over-month

  • Top 10 exception drivers (before vs. after)

  • Auto-receive success rates

  • Percentage reduction in tax/shipping exceptions

Customers who follow this approach typically see:

  • 20–40% reduction in exceptions within 90 days

  • Major improvements in user satisfaction

  • A measurable boost in straight-through invoice processing

Final Thoughts

Improving your “invoices without exceptions” KPI is not about relaxing controls—it’s about applying the right controls in the right places. The strategies in this article come directly from working with many SAP Ariba customers, across industries, who have successfully increased adoption and reduced AP workload through targeted process and configuration optimization.

If your KPI is below best-in-class, use this as a starting point. A few focused adjustments can create a major lift in processing speed, supplier satisfaction, and AP efficiency.

entry.title: Non‑PO Invoices: When to Use Them and When Not
entry.content:
Invoices submitted without a reference to a purchase order or a contract are common in many organizations. For their lack of reference, they are referred as non-PO Invoices in the invoice processing systems across the AP scope.

Non‑PO invoices solve real problems but also introduce risks. In this short guide I'm trying to explain how often they are used, when they make sense, what risks they represent, and practical actions to be taken by procurement leaders.

How much they’re used

Typical usage of non-PO invoices by organizations lies in 5–30% interval of invoice volume and 5–25% of AP spend. This can differ per industry segments, but higher ratios exceeding 30% may be indicators of slow PO processes, high services spend, many small vendors, or immature procurement systems. For organizations it points to opportunities for improvements in their efficiency and compliance targets.

When non‑PO invoices make sense

There are cases, where non-PO invoices are unavoidable and include number of scenarios that can be handled without loosing control:

  • Emergency or safety‑critical purchases where creating a PO would cause unwanted delays
  • Professional services billed on milestones, time & materials, or when scope/price is agreed after work begins
    (unless they are covered by contracts to which the invoices could be referring to)
  • Suppliers that cannot accept POs (small/legacy suppliers in challenging regions)
  • Very low‑value transactions where PO overhead exceeds benefit
  • Highly exceptional cases, when PO cannot be created, e.g. system outages, transitions, etc.

When non‑PO invoices are NOT a good practice

Sometimes organizations keep their "long term" legacy practices, because "it is so comfortable to do it our time-proven way". Many opportunities can be missed, more manual effort in the invoice matching activities is required, and organizations tend to run in circles, unable to unlock the trap.

Try to avoid the following (or similar) areas, where non-PO invoices are part of the picture:  

  • Repeat purchases from the same supplier that should be on contract or catalog
  • High‑value or strategic spend where PO terms protect pricing, delivery and liability
  • Categories with clear opportunities for consolidation or volume discounts
  • Environments with known fraud or duplicate payment risk and weak AP controls

When there is an overlay between the existing structured buying channels (catalog/contract spend), or guarding commercial terms (payment/delivery/liability), non-PO invoices can be easily replaced. This will deliver efficiency improvements. 

Pros and cons

Decision makers in the procurement organizations might be aware of the positive and negative aspects of the non-PO invoice practice in their purchasing processes. Here is the overview:

  •  Pros
    • Speed and flexibility for urgent or complex purchases
    • Preserves supplier relationships when suppliers won’t accept POs
    • Simpler for T&M or milestone invoicing for services (if tools for contract compliance/services spend are unavailable)
  • Cons
    • Higher maverick spend, weak spend control
    • Low visibility into budget, contracts and supplier performance
    • Higher AP processing costs and more invoice exceptions
    • Increased risk of fraud or duplicate payments
    • Slower month‑end reconciliation and weaker sourcing discipline

Practical policy decisions and actions

  1. Define acceptable exceptions
    • Publish a short list of allowed cases (emergency, validated supplier, low‑value threshold, services)
    • require a business justification field on every non‑PO invoice

  2. Set clear thresholds & approval matrix
    • Use amount thresholds tied to approval levels
      (e.g., Dept Manager for <500; Directorfor<5k; Procurement+Finance for larger amounts)
  3. Automate non‑PO workflows
    • Force mandatory fields (exception reason, GL code, cost center)
    • Route approvals automatically, and capture justification in the AR/AP system

  4. Monitor & report monthly
    • Track count and value of non‑PO invoices, repeat suppliers, time‑to‑approval, and % of total AP spend
    • Create alerts for repeat non‑PO suppliers

  5. Convert repeat non‑PO spend
    • Onboard frequent non‑PO suppliers to catalogs, negotiated contracts or a managed marketplace (SpotBuy) within 60–90 days

  6. Strengthen supplier onboarding
    • Ensure vendors used for non‑PO invoices have basic validations (tax forms, bank details, insurance) before payments over a threshold

  7. Balance convenience with control
    • Offer low‑friction PO alternatives (catalogs, SpotBuy, pre‑approved templates) to reduce the need of non‑PO invoices

  8. Audit & continuous improvement
    • Periodically audit samples of non‑PO invoices for compliance, fraud indicators and opportunities to source differently

Quick target benchmarks 

How do you know, where you stand and whether you are successful in achieving your targets? You might want to use this simple guide of measurable process metrics to help you gain visibility of the non-PO invoicing process:

  • Healthy: non‑PO invoice volume <15% and non‑PO spend <10% of AP
  • Risky: non‑PO invoice volume 15–30% or non‑PO spend 10–25% — implement remediation plan
  • Alarm: non‑PO invoice volume >30% or non‑PO spend >25% — immediate controls, audit, and supplier enablement required

 

Final takeaway

Non‑PO invoices should be a controlled exception, not the norm. Make sure to limit their use with a clear policy, automate approvals and data capture, track them closely, and convert recurring non‑PO purchases into PO‑based channels where better savings, visibility and control can be delivered.

entry.title: Managing Invoices with SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Managing supplier invoices is much like 'heartbeat' of the Accounts Payable (AP) department. The goal mostly remains the same for all organizations: Accuracy, Speed, and Compliance. The general invoice management lifecycle follows a standard 4-step journey.

  • Receipt & Capture: Invoices arrive via email, paper, or digital portals. Traditionally, this required manual data entry.
  • Validation & Matching: Checking if the invoice matches the Purchase Order (PO) and the Goods Receipt (GR). This is '3-way matching'.
  • Approval Workflow: Routing the invoice to the responsible person for approval based on the department or spend amount.
  • Posting & Payment: Once approved, the payment process is initiated.

When it comes to SAP, there have been various invoicing solutions with their own strengths. Some details of these can be found in these posts - Invoicing in SAP Ariba & AI in SAP Ariba Invoicing - Intelligent Invoice Conversion. 

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution is based on cloud-first approach leveraging SAP Business Technology Platform with AI-powered OCR capabilities and multi-system connectivity. It isn't just a digital filing cabinet; it is a central nervous system for Accounts Payable. It takes the 'heavy lifting' out of invoice receipt and lets the AP team focus on strategic cash flow management rather than typing in numbers. It helps the organization to move from a world of fragmented, manual tasks to a centralized, touchless cloud environment. For a quick 1 minute intro, kindly refer SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management Intro Video.

This blog post provides a comprehensive look at the SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution and its surrounding ecosystem. It serves as a centralized hub of resources to help understand the core concepts, evaluate the solution for business needs, and navigate the implementation process.

Invoice Management - Challenges & Need for Modern Solution

Following figure explains the typical challenges with traditional Invoice Management solutions/practices in a nutshell.

Invoice Management Challenges

 The following table explains the cost implications arising out of these challenges.

Challenges & Cost Implications

Figure below explains the business drivers for modern invoicing solution.

Business Drivers for Modern Invoicing Solution

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management (CIM) - Solution Overview

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management is a cloud-native solution on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for receiving and managing supplier invoices from multiple connected systems. The solution enables centralized invoice processing with embedded OCR capabilities, automated workflows for approvals or seeking more information, and seamless integration with backend ERP systems. Both PO-Based & Non-PO Invoices are fully supported.

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management must be connected to at least one system, but a combination of multiple system connections is also possible. The following systems can be connected:

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  2. SAP S/4HANA
  3. SAP ERP
  4. Classic Invoicing Solution (SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing, SAP Ariba Invoice Management)

For product tour, information sheet, and pricing, kindly refer the page SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management​. For complete process overview, kindly refer this 23 minutes video SAP Central Invoice Management - Deep Dive.

Prominent Solution Features:

  1. Multi-Channel Invoice Processing: Supports invoice receipt through file upload, email extraction, structured data inbound API, and Business Network integration.
  2. Embedded OCR Technology: Native optical character recognition capabilities for automated data extraction from paper-based and PDF invoices with drag-and-drop interface.
  3. Centralized Workflow Management: Single worklist for accounts payable teams with visibility across all channels and streamlined processing with prioritization.
  4. Intelligent Automation: Background verification jobs for PO-based invoices with automatic posting or manual adjustment routing based on tolerance levels.
  5. Easy View & Navigation: Supports the display of invoice attachments in a split screen, as well as a seamless navigation to SAP Fiori apps for invoices or SAP GUI transactions from connected systems.
  6. Access Control: Provides various options to authorize specific invoice access to different user groups.Refer SAP Help on SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management for more details.

CIM - Key Components

CIM has 4 key components as seen below.

CIM - Key Components

CIM - Integration Ecosystem

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management can be integrated with systems as depicted in figure below. Kindly refer CIM Architecture & CIM API Reference for more details.

CIM - Integration Ecosystem

CIM - Business Case

Implementation of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution can help manage the challenges and bring in benefits as shown in figure below.

CIM - Business Case

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management - Process Flow

An ideal process enabled by CIM may sound like this:

Company receives a PDF invoice via email. The system automatically extracts the invoice using IRPA Bot, uploads it to Central Invoice Management, and applies OCR to extract supplier data. For PO-based invoices, the system automatically matches against purchase orders and goods receipts. If within tolerance, the invoice posts automatically. If discrepancies exist, it routes to an AP clerk for review through the centralized worklist, where they can make corrections and resubmit for processing. For complete CIM process flow, kindly refer Process Flow Diagram.

Typical stages in the process are:

CIM - Process Stages

For a quick overview of Invoice Upload and Edit process, refer this 3 minutes video. For more details, please refer SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management User Guide. A typical CIM invoicing process flow has been illustrated with screenshots as below.

CIM - Homepage

Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally - List of Invoices

You begin the process by uploading the supplier invoice, single attachment per invoice. It can be manual or can use one of the various inbound channels to automatically upload invoices. Once your invoice has been uploaded, the Document Information Extraction service is used for optical character recognition (OCR). For proper OCR processing, a minimum of 320x320 pixel image resolution is suggested.

You need to select Company Code and then upload one or many Invoice PDF files. You can upload your invoices in XML (for Germany only), PDF, PNG, TIFF or JPEG format. Invoices can also be imported from connected systems. A unique Central Invoice ID is assigned to each Invoice and we also see different Invoice Document Number from the connected system for each.

The filters 'Connected System Name' and 'Company Code' are interdependent. For example, if you select a specific connected system, the values for Company Code include data from the selected Connected System only.

Upload Supplier Invoices Centrally - Invoice PDF Upload

CIM Invoice can have 3 statuses in the app 'Upload Supplier Invoices Centrally'. They are - Draft, With errors, & Posted.

  • Draft: Some mandatory fields are missing in CIM Invoice and Process Step says 'Manual Adjustment Required'. Some fields can be configured to be auto-filled.
  • With errors: Invoice was attempted in connected system and has failed validations & needs manual action.
  • Posted: Invoice is successfully posted in connected system.

For each uploaded invoice, the system logs the time and date of the upload and the user who uploaded the file in the app. The system doesn’t check for duplicates among the uploaded invoices.

Upload Supplier Invoices Centrally - Uploaded Invoice in Draft Status

For invoices intended for a classic invoicing solution (e.g. invoice processing systems such as SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing or SAP Ariba Invoice Management), the file size must not exceed 20 MB (50 MB for SAP connected system). 

We need to keep the page or browser tab open while the upload is in progress. You can select a new list of files to upload while the current upload is still in progress. If you enter a new company code and description, they’re applied to the newly selected files only.

The uploaded file becomes an attachment to the draft invoice. After an invoice is uploaded, it's submitted to the connected system for verification. Once you have successfully uploaded your supplier invoice, the Document Information Extraction process starts. Additionally, templates can be used for document information extraction.

Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally - Document Information Extraction

When you view an uploaded invoice, you may notice errors in the information that is extracted and displayed. You can use the Manage Document Information Extraction Templates app to edit the extraction errors in the document. For more details, refer Manage Document Information Extraction Templates.

For Peppol and SAP Business Network invoices, the Document Information Extraction process step is skipped, as the optical character recognition (OCR) and information extraction service is not required.

When using the Document Information Extraction service for the first time, the results may contain mistakes. To improve the information extraction, you must train the system using, for example, templates or other learning methods. If the confidence score of an extracted invoice field is lower than 50%, the field is not saved to the draft invoice in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management. Document Information Extraction typically provides extraction results for an average document in about 30 seconds.

Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally - Next Process Steps

The invoice 'Process Step' and 'Status' are displayed in the invoice list and on the invoice detail page. Process step describes the current step of the invoice process that is being completed. Within SAP Ariba CIM, the process steps vary depending on whether the received invoice is intended for an SAP connected system or a classic invoicing system. Status describes the processing status of an invoice. For more details on process steps and status, kindly refer Checking Invoice Status and Process Step.

Manual Adjustment Required (Ex. Missing Tax Code)

After Manual Adjustment - Accepted-Posted

Open Invoice - Invoice in the Connected System

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management - Implementation Considerations

CIM - Integration Scenarios

SAP Ariba CIM provides flexible connectivity options to bridge the gap between various ERPs and invoice sources. The table below explores the potential scenarios, suitable integration methods and data paths for achieving a modernized, centralized invoicing ecosystem.

CIM Implementation Consideration - Integration Scenarios

CIM - Implementation Roadmap

The transition to SAP Ariba CIM can be managed through a structured 4-phase journey. Such roadmap can align high-level strategic objectives with specific technical milestones to ensure a seamless migration. The roadmap shown below can help as a starting point.

CIM Implementation Consideration - Roadmap

CIM - System Setup

With the SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management, you can have 3 SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management tenants: one tenant for production, and up to two tenants for testing. You need to create one different SAP BTP subaccount for each of these tenants.

Activities needed to setup a CIM system have been detailed in the guides below.

  • CIM Setup with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • CIM Setup with SAP S/4HANA
  • CIM Admin Guide

CIM - Administration / Configuration

CIM system can be configured further to add new connected systems, schedule import of master data, manage document information templates, set business & validations rules, etc. Screen below shows the different config options available. Kindly refer CIM Admin Guide for further details.

CIM - Administration & Configuration

Other Related Topics

Use of AI

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management uses multiple AI technologies under SAP Business AI initiative to transform invoice processing from manual, error-prone operations into intelligent, automated workflows. The solution integrates machine learning, robotic process automation, document information extraction, and generative AI to drastically reduce manual workload for accounts payable teams.

AI Technologies leveraged in CIM

  • Document Information Extraction - OCR with AI Enhancement: Automatically extracts relevant data from supplier invoices using both optical character recognition (OCR) and non-OCR AI processing.
  • Machine Learning for Data Recommendations: Provides intelligent line-item recommendations for missing G/L accounts, cost centers, and WBS elements in draft invoices. It gets trained on company's historical invoice data to learn patterns and make accurate predictions.
  • Robotic Process Automation (RPA): Automates repetitive, manual business processes using virtual software robots. It can handle tasks such as email processing, file extraction, data interactions from multiple sources, and high-volume operations.
  • Generative AI Integration: Adds creative capabilities to traditional data analysis and decision-making functions. It is integrated across SAP Business AI portfolio for process automation and enhanced customer interactions.

Partner Enablement

With the Test, Demo and Development (TDD) license, Partners can have one SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management tenant. They can use this tenant for test, demo and development purpose. SAP BTP subaccount for this tenant must be created.

Please contact tdd@sap.com for partner licensing inquiries and TDD entitlement requests. Also refer the page Test, demo, and development: Subscription on Partner Portal for more details. For Country - India, direct links for 2 CIM related TDD licenses are:

  • Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP Central Invoice Management
  • Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP Central Invoice Management, inbound processing

For Partners having access to Content Discovery, online & offline demo can be done using this script - Integrated Central Invoice Management with Public Cloud.

Feature Releases

SAP has transitioned from a traditional quarterly release model to a more agile monthly release strategy with quarterly major updates for SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management. This enables faster delivery of customer-requested features and continuous improvement of invoice processing capabilities. For more details, kindly refer What's New in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management.

Conclusion

Navigating the complexities of a multi-ERP landscape often leads to fragmented data and manual inefficiencies. However, as we have explored, the challenges of traditional invoice handling are effectively addressed by the AI-driven capabilities of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management.

In summary, the limitations of legacy invoice management are clear, but so is the solution. By centralizing visibility, automating data extraction on SAP BTP, and reducing manual intervention, CIM does more than just process invoices—it transforms the AP department into a strategic asset. For any organization looking to optimize their spend management, adopting CIM is the logical next step in their digital transformation journey.
